page.title: International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas

revision.comment: Added citation, trying to reduce bias
revision.text:
The '''International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT)''' is an [[intergovernmental organization]] responsible for the management and conservation of tuna and tuna-like species in the [[Atlantic Ocean]] and adjacent seas.{{cite web|title=ICCAT|url=https://www.iccat.int/en/|website=The International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas|accessdate=4 April 2018}} The organization was established in 1969, at a conference in [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]], and operates in [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]] and [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. The organisation has been strongly criticised by scientists for its repeated failure to conserve the [[sustainability]] of the tuna [[fishery]] by consistently supporting over-fishing – an internal review branded ICCAT's policies on the eastern Atlantic bluefin tuna fishery a "travesty of fisheries management", and an "international disgrace".{{Cite web|url=http://www.ngo.grida.no/wwfneap/Publication/Submissions/OSPAR2008/WWF_MASH08_BFT_Annex3.pdf|title=Why are urgent, radical measures necessary to ensure the survival of Mediterranean and East Atlantic bluefin tuna?|author=WWF|date=2009-10-29|accessdate=2009-11-15|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605183020/http://www.ngo.grida.no/wwfneap/Publication/Submissions/OSPAR2008/WWF_MASH08_BFT_Annex3.pdf|archivedate=2011-06-05|df=}} [[Conservation movement|Conservationists]] often refer to ICCAT as "The International Conspiracy to Catch All Tuna".''BBC news'', [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/7040011.stm Last rites for a marine marvel?] However, in recent years the organization seems to be turning around. For the most iconic species within its management, the Eastern Bluefin Tuna, a very strict recovery plan was adopted. It is too early to judge its final outcome, but initial indications are encouraging. In general, ICCAT contracting parties seem to have agreed to steer the organization into a direction of relying on sound science, insisting on compliance and following a good governance model. ==Species under management== Tuna and tuna-like fishes are highly [[Fish migration|migratory]], and [[Fish stock|stocks]] cross numerous [[territorial waters|international boundaries]]. ICCAT is involved in management of 30 species, including the [[Bluefin tuna|Atlantic bluefin]] (''Thunnus thynnus thynnus''), [[yellowfin tuna|yellowfin]] (''T. albacares''), [[albacore]] (''T. alalunga'') and [[bigeye tuna]] (''T. obesus''); from the billfishes, [[swordfish]] (''Xiphias gladius''), [[white marlin]] (''Tetrapturus albidus''), [[Atlantic blue marlin|blue marlin]] (''Makaira nigricans''), [[sailfish]] (''Istiophorus albicans''); mackerels such as spotted [[Spanish mackerel]] (''Scomberomorus maculatus'') and [[king mackerel]] (''S. cavalla''); and, small tunas like [[skipjack tuna]] (''Katsuwonus pelamis''). ==Work carried out by the ICCAT== Scientists participating in ICCAT carry out studies on [[biometry]], [[ecology|fisheries ecology]], and [[oceanography]], focusing on the effects of fishing on tuna stock abundance. They also collect and analyse fisheries statistics which are relative to conditions the management of resources. ICCAT is also involved in work on data for other fish species that are caught during tuna fishing ("[[bycatch]]" - principally sharks) in the Atlantic and surrounding area, and which are not investigated by another international fishery organization. Based on scientific and other information, such as fishery statistics and stock assessments provided by members, each year the Commission decides on conservation and management measures aimed at maintaining target stocks at levels that permit the maximum sustainable catch for food and other purposes. ==Criticism== ICCAT is widely criticised by environmental bodies for having short-term policies that favour fisherman over the long-term conservation of the species. Clover, Charles. 2004. [[The End of the Line: How Overfishing Is Changing the World and What We Eat]]. Ebury Press, London. {{ISBN|0-09-189780-7}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2008/may/11/fishing.food|title=How the world's oceans are running out of fish|first=Alex|last=Renton|newspaper=[[The Observer]]|date=2008-05-11|accessdate=2008-05-11}} In November 2008, ICCAT ignored the advice of their scientists that quotas should not exceed 15,000 tonnes per year – which had been determined as the maximum sustainable yield – and instead set quotas at 22,000 tonnes.{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/7746965.stm|title=EU condemned on tuna 'mockery'|first=Richard|last=Black| publisher=[[BBC News Online]]|date=2009-10-29|accessdate=2009-11-15}} An independent review of ICCAT, commissioned by the organisation themselves, concluded that their policies on the eastern Atlantic bluefin tuna fishery are a "travesty of fisheries management", and an "international disgrace". Dr Sergi Tudela, head of [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF]] Mediterranean's fisheries programme, said "Today's outcome is a recipe for economic as well as biological bankruptcy with the European Union squarely to blame. ICCAT's string of successive failures leaves us little option now but to seek effective remedies through trade measures and extending the boycott of retailers, restaurants, chefs and consumers".{{Cite web|url=http://www.panda.org/who_we_are/wwf_offices/poland/?151021/Tuna-commission-comes-up-with-quota-disgrace-not-a-decisionquot|last=WWF|title=Tuna commission comes up with "a disgrace, not a decision"|publisher=[[World Wide Fund for Nature]]|date=2008-11-24|accessdate=2009-11-22}} In November 2009, ICCAT's scientific advisors announced that a total ban on international trade in Atlantic tuna was justified, based on the decline in the tuna fishery population to less than 15% of its original size.{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/8331113.stm|title=Tuna ban "justified" by science|first=Richard|last=Black| publisher=[[BBC News Online]]|date=2009-10-29|accessdate=2009-11-15}} However, later in the same month, ICCAT recommended catch quotas of 13,500 tonnes per year. This was met by sharp criticisms from environmental organisations, and prompted calls for alternative methods to regulate Atlantic tuna fisheries, such as protection under [[CITES]]. Susan Lieberman, Director of International Policy for the [[Pew Environment Group]] said
Since its inception, the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas has been driven by short-term commercial fishing interests, not the conservation ethic implied by its name....ICCAT's actions and inactions highlight the need to take these issues to CITES—the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. The ICCAT fisheries managers have shown scant interest in the long-term preservation of the key resources they are supposed to manage. It is now time to turn to other bodies to seek the needed protections that ICCAT has failed to provide.{{Cite web|url=http://news.mongabay.com/2009/1115-hance_iccat.html|title=ICCAT fails to protect Atlantic Tuna - again|first=Jeremy|last=Hance|date=2009-11-15|accessdate=2009-11-15}}
The US [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] (NOAA) released a statement with strongly worded criticism, saying that the new agreement was "a marked improvement over the current rules, but it is insufficient to guarantee the long-term viability of either the fish or the fishery".{{Cite web|url=http://www.noaanews.noaa.gov/stories2009/20091116_iccat.html|title=NOAA Issues Statement on ICCAT Annual Meeting|author=NOAA|date=2009-11-16|accessdate=2009-11-16}} ==Recent Developments== In recent years ICCAT adopted a draconic recovery plan for Eastern Bluefin Tuna, which led to the reduction of the total allowable catches from 27,500 in 2007 to 13,400 tons in 2014. Apart from reduced total allowable catches, the recovery plan also introduced strict monitoring, reporting and control measures Over the years the plan seemed to produce results and recently earlier critics have welcome the plan and the action undertaken by ICCAT. In November 2012 Susan Lieberman, international policy director of Pew Environment Group stated that "It is encouraging that ICCAT listened to the recommendations of its own scientists and agreed to keep catch limits for bluefin tuna within their advice. This decision will give this depleted species a fighting chance to continue on the path to recovery after decades of overfishing and mismanagement". {{Cite web|url=http://www.pewtrusts.org/en/about/news-room/press-releases/2012/11/19/iccat-follows-scientific-advice-on-atlantic-bluefin-tuna-makes-some-progress-on-sharks-efforts-to-combat-illegal-fishing|title=ICCAT follows scientific advice on atlantic bluefin tuna|author=Pew Environment Group|date=2012-11-19|accessdate=2014-08-01}} In November 2013 Dr Sergi Tudela, Head of Fisheries at WWF Mediterranean said: “WWF congratulates ICCAT member countries for sticking to science again this year regarding bluefin tuna quotas in the East Atlantic and Mediterranean. This is a good sign for the credibility of ICCAT. However, failure to address countries’ failure to comply with rules remains an issue of grave concern”. {{Cite web|url=http://www.wwf.org.uk/about_wwf/press_centre/?unewsid=6910|title=Atlantic tuna commission sticks to science on bluefin tuna|author=WWF|date=2013-11-25|accessdate=2014-08-01}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.iccat.int}} *[http://www.ecolex.org/ecolex/ledge/view/RecordDetails;DIDPFDSIjsessionid=D9BB277000DBC9205BB8C72E4AB059F6?id=TRE-000871&index=treaties Protocol Relating to Modification of the International Convention for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas], Treaty available in ECOLEX-the gateway to environmental law (English) {{tuna}} {{DEFAULTSORT:International Commission For The Conservation Of Atlantic Tunas}} [[Category:Fisheries agencies]] [[Category:Fishing industry]] [[Category:Intergovernmental organizations established by treaty]] [[Category:Tuna]] [[Category:Atlantic Ocean]] [[Category:Organisations based in Madrid]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1969]]

{{Infobox Journal | cover = | discipline = physical [[speleology]], biospeleology | website = http://www.ijs.speleo.it/ | publisher = Società Speleologica Italiana | country = [[Italy]] | abbreviation = | frequency = Biannual | history = 1964-present | link1 = http://www.ijs.speleo.it/archive.php | link1-name = Online access | ISSN = 0392-6672 | eISSN = 1827-806X }} The '''''International Journal of Speleology''''' is since 1978 the official [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] [[scientific journal]] of the ''Union Internationale de Spéléologie''. Since 1981 it has been published by the [[Società Speleologica Italiana]].
The ''International Journal of Speleology'' is divided into four sections: Botany-Microbiology, Zoology, Geology-Geomorphology, and Abstract-News. The first issue was edited by G. Claus (US), subsequently two other editors were added: R. Husson (France) and G Nicholas (USA). The first two volumes were published by the J. Kramer Verlag ([[Germany]]), followed by Swets & Zeitlinger N.V. (The [[Netherlands]]).
In 1972 R. Husson became [[editor in chief]] and nine volumes were issued in the period 1964 to 1977 until the cost of printing requested a radical change. In 1978 the journal became the official journal of the [[Union Internationale de Spéléologie]] and it was published in [[Italy]] where the cost of printing was lower.
In 1981 V. Sbordoni (Italy) became editor in chief. In the meantime the Società Speleologica Italiana acquired the property of the journal which was printed with a contribution of the Italian Ministry for Culture and Environment, the [[Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche]], and the [[University of Trieste]].
In the second half of the 1990s the Museo di Speleologia "V. Rivera" also contributed to the financial support of the journal. The issues of the journal were alternatively dedicated to biospeleology and physical speleology until 1998 when the journal was split into two different series: "A" for Biospeleology (which ceased publication in 2003) and "B" for Physical Speleology.
In addition to the regular issues of the journal, in 1996 a "Manual for Karst water analysis" by W.E. Krawczyk was printed.
== See also == * [[List of scientific journals]] * [[List of scientific journals in earth and atmospheric sciences]]

{{Infobox lake | name = Manasarovar | native_name = | image = Yaks-Kailash-Manasarovar.jpg | caption = Lake Manasarovar with Mount [[Kailash]] in a distance. | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = [[Tibet Autonomous Region]], [[Tibet]] | coords = {{coord|30.65|81.45|type:waterbody|display=inline,title}} | type = | inflow = | outflow = | catchment = | basin_countries = | length = | width = | area = {{convert|410|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} | depth = | max-depth = {{convert|90|m|ft|abbr=on}} | volume = | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = {{convert|4590|m|ft|abbr=on}} | islands = | cities = | frozen = Winter }} '''Lake Manasarovar''' ({{bo|t=མ་ཕམ་གཡུ་མཚོ།|w=ma pham g.yu mtsho}}; [[Chinese language|Chinese]]: {{lang-zh|}}玛旁雍錯 ([[Simplified Chinese|simplified]]), {{lang-zh|}}瑪旁雍錯([[Traditional Chinese|traditional]]) also called '''Mapam Yumtso''', is a high altitude freshwater [[lake]] fed by the Kailash Glaciers{{cite book |last= Brockman |first= Norbert |date= 2011 |title= Encyclopedia of Sacred Places, Volume 1 |url= https://books.google.co.in/books?id=JkSk4euA-TEC&pg=PA356&dq=manasarova+worlds+highest+freshwater&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiN6P7UlObWAhXIwI8KHT9fARcQ6AEIWDAJ#v=onepage&q=manasarova%20worlds%20highest%20freshwater&f=false |publisher= ABC-CLIO |page= 356 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20171010210910/https://books.google.co.in/books?id=JkSk4euA-TEC&pg=PA356&dq=manasarova+worlds+highest+freshwater&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiN6P7UlObWAhXIwI8KHT9fARcQ6AEIWDAJ#v=onepage&q=manasarova%20worlds%20highest%20freshwater&f=false |archivedate= 2017-10-10 |df= }} near [[Mount Kailash]] in the [[Tibet]]. The lake is revered a sacred place in four religions: [[Hinduism]], [[Bön]], [[Buddhism]] and [[Jainism]]. == Etymology == The Sanskrit word "''Manasarovar''" (मानसरोवर) is a combination of two Sanskrit words; "''Mánas''" (मानस) meaning "''mind (in its widest sense as applied to all the mental powers), intellect, intelligence, understanding, perception, sense, conscience''"{{cite web |url= http://faculty.washington.edu/prem/mw/m.html |title= Monier-Williams Sanskrit-English Dictionary |last= Williams |first= Monier |website= faculty.washington.edu |quote= mánas n. mind (in its widest sense as applied to all the mental powers), intellect, intelligence, understanding, perception, sense, conscience, will RV. &c. &c. (in phil. the internal organ or antaḥ-karaṇa of perception and cognition, the faculty or instrument through which thoughts enter or by which objects of sense affect the soul IW. 53
• in this sense manas is always is always regarded as distinct from ātman and puruṣa, 'spirit or soul' and belonging only to the body, like which it is – except in the Nyāya – considered perishable |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121203191432/http://faculty.washington.edu/prem/mw/m.html |archivedate= 2012-12-03 |df= }} while "''sarovara''" (सरोवर) means "''a lake or large pond''".{{cite web |url= http://faculty.washington.edu/prem/mw/s.html |title= Monier-Williams Sanskrit-English Dictionary |last= Williams |first= Monier |website= faculty.washington.edu |quote= sarovara ○vara n. (accord. to some also m.) a lake or large pond, any piece of water deep enough for the lotus Kāv. Pur. &c |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150520235218/http://faculty.washington.edu/prem/mw/s.html |archivedate= 2015-05-20 |df= }} == Geography == [[File:Mansarovar map.jpg|thumb|Map of the region]] Lake Manasarovar lies at {{convert|4,590|m|abbr=on}} above mean sea level, a relatively high elevation for a large freshwater lake on the mostly saline lake-studded [[Tibetan Plateau]]. Lake Manasa sarovar is relatively round in shape with the circumference of {{convert|88|km|mi|1|abbr=on}}. Its depth reaches a maximum depth of {{convert|90|m|ft|abbr=on}}{{citation needed|date=February 2012}} and its surface area is {{convert|320|km2|1|abbr=on}}. It is connected to nearby [[Lake Rakshastal]] by the natural [[Ganga Chhu]] channel. Lake Manasarovar is near the source of the [[Sutlej]], which is the easternmost large tributary of the [[Indus River|Sindhu]]. Nearby are the sources of the [[Brahmaputra River]], the [[Indus River]], and the [[Ghaghara]], an important tributary of the [[Ganges]]. Lake Manasarovar overflows into Lake Rakshastal which is a salt-water [[endorheic basin|endorheic lake]]. These lakes used to be part of the Sutlej basin and were separated due to tectonic activity. ==Climate== {{Weather box|width=auto |metric first=y |single line=y |location = Lake Manasarovar |Jan high C = -3.2 |Feb high C = -2.0 |Mar high C = 0.9 |Apr high C = 6.4 |May high C = 10.2 |Jun high C = 13.7 |Jul high C = 13.7 |Aug high C = 13.1 |Sep high C = 13.1 |Oct high C = 11.1 |Nov high C = 6.5 |Dec high C = 1.0 |Jan mean C = -8.9 |Feb mean C = -7.6 |Mar mean C = -4.2 |Apr mean C = -0.1 |May mean C = 3.1 |Jun mean C = 7.1 |Jul mean C = 8.4 |Aug mean C = 8.0 |Sep mean C = 8.0 |Oct mean C = 5.4 |Nov mean C = -0.2 |Dec mean C = -5.1 |year mean C = |Jan low C = -14.5 |Feb low C = -13.1 |Mar low C = -9.2 |Apr low C = -6.6 |May low C = -4.0 |Jun low C = 0.6 |Jul low C = 3.1 |Aug low C = 3.0 |Sep low C = -0.2 |Oct low C = -6.8 |Nov low C = -11.1 |Dec low C = -13.3 |precipitation colour = green |Jan precipitation mm = 52 |Feb precipitation mm = 34 |Mar precipitation mm = 52 |Apr precipitation mm = 30 |May precipitation mm = 26 |Jun precipitation mm = 40 |Jul precipitation mm = 125 |Aug precipitation mm = 135 |Sep precipitation mm = 66 |Oct precipitation mm = 29 |Nov precipitation mm = 7 |Dec precipitation mm = 18 |source 1 = [https://en.climate-data.org/location/968516/ Climate-Data.org] }} == Religious significance == [[File:Manasarovar lake.jpg|300px|right|thumb|View from Chiu Gompa Monastery]] [[File:Mt Kailash sat.jpg|thumb|300px|Satellite view of lakes Manasarovar (right) and Rakshastal with [[Mount Kailash]] in the background]] [[File:Lake Manasa Sarovar 01.jpg|thumb|300x300px|Lake Manasarovar.]] === In Hinduism === According to [[Hinduism]], the lake was first created in the mind of the Lord Brahma after which it manifested on Earth.Charles Allen. (1999). ''The Search for [[Shangri-la]]: A Journey into Tibetan History'', p. 10. Little, Brown and Company. Reprint: Abacus, London. 2000. {{ISBN|0-349-11142-1}}. In Hinduism, Lake Manasarovar is a personification of purity, and one who drinks water from the lake will go to the abode of [[Shiva]] after death. He is believed to be cleansed of all his sins committed over even a hundred lifetimes. Like [[Mount Kailash]], Lake Manasarovar is a place of pilgrimage, attracting religious people from [[India]], [[Nepal]], [[Tibet]] and neighboring countries. Bathing in Manasarovar and drinking its water is believed by Hindus to cleanse all sins.{{Cite web|url=http://www.kailash-yatra.org/about-mansarovar-lake.html#main_articles_sec|title=About Holy Manasarovar Lake – Kailash Yatra|last=Kailash Yatra|website=www.kailash-yatra.org|access-date=2016-04-25|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160502155525/http://www.kailash-yatra.org/about-mansarovar-lake.html#main_articles_sec|archivedate=2016-05-02|df=}} [[Pilgrimage]] tours are organized regularly, especially from India, the most famous of which is the yearly "Kailash Manas Sarovar Yatra". Pilgrims come to take ceremonial baths in the waters of the lake. Lake Manasarovar has long been viewed by the pilgrims as being nearby to the sources of four great rivers of Asia, namely the [[Brahmaputra River|Brahmaputra,]] [[Ghaghara]], Sindhu and [[Sutlej]], thus it is an axial point which has been thronged to by pilgrims for thousands of years. The region was closed to pilgrims from the outside following the [[Battle of Chamdo]]; no foreigners were allowed between 1951 and 1980. After the 1980s it has again become a part of the Indian pilgrim trail.In Search of Myths & Heroes By Michael Wood According to the Hinduism, the lake was first created in the mind of [[Brahma]] after which it manifested on Earth. Hence it is called "Manasa sarovaram", which is a combination of the [[Sanskrit]] words for "mind" and "lake". The lake is also supposed to be the summer abode of the [[Hamsa (bird)|hamsa]]. Considered to be sacred, the hamsa is an important element in the symbology of the subcontinent, representing wisdom and beauty.Eckard Schleberger, Die Indische Götterwelt.'' Eugen Diederich Verlag. 1997 {{de icon}} According to Hindu theology, there are five sacred lakes; collectively called ''Panch-Sarovar''; Mansarovar, [[Siddhpur|Bindu Sarovar]], [[Narayan Sarovar]], [[Pampa Sarovar]] and [[Pushkar Lake|Pushkar Sarovar]]. They are also mentioned in [[Shrimad Bhagavata Purana]].{{cite web |author= |url=http://kutchguide.blogspot.com/2011/03/narayan-sarovar-temple-in-kutch-city.html |title=Narayan Sarovar Temple in Kutch ~ KACHCHH GUIDE |publisher=Kutchguide.blogspot.com |date=2010-12-19 |accessdate=2015-07-27 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150723073313/http://kutchguide.blogspot.com/2011/03/narayan-sarovar-temple-in-kutch-city.html |archivedate=2015-07-23 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.gujaratguideonline.com/Kutch-Places.html |title=Kutch Visiting Places and Tourist Attraction : Kutch Guide – Gujarat |publisher=Gujaratguideonline.com |accessdate=2015-07-27 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924024153/http://www.gujaratguideonline.com/Kutch-Places.html |archivedate=2015-09-24 |df= }}[https://books.google.com/books?id=nxtnsT8CdZ4C&pg=PA112&dq=narayan+sarovar&hl=en&ei=jZa1TbzPDsrKrAe0j-3IDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFIQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=narayan%20sarovar&f=false] Encyclopaedia of tourism resources in India, Volume 2 By Manohar Sajnani The People belong to this region is called [[Manasarovar]]iya.Most of Them follow Hindu Religion are belong to [[Koli people|Koli]] tribe called [[Manasarovar|Manasarovariya Patel]] or [[Mandhatri|Mandhata Patel]] claimed that their tribe belong to ancient King [[Mandhatri|Mandhata]] of [[Ikshvaku dynasty|suryavansha of Ikshvaku dynasty]] and There is mountain named after his name called [[Gurla Mandhata]] is the highest peak of the [[Nalakankar Himal]] for glorify his achievement. === In the Bon religion === The [[Bon]] religion is also associated with the holy place of [[Zhang Zhung Meri]] sacred deity. When [[Tonpa Shenrab Miwoche|Tonpa Shenrab]], the founder of the Bon religion, visited Tibet for the first time – from [[Tagzig Olmo Lung Ring|Tagzig Wolmo Lungring]] – he washed in the lake. === In Buddhism === [[Buddhism|Buddhists]] associate the lake with the legendary lake [[Anavatapta]] ([[Sanskrit]]; [[Pali]] ''Anotatta'') where [[Maya (mother of the Buddha)|Maya]] is believed to have conceived [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]]. The lake has a few [[vihara|monasteries]] on its shores, the most notable of which is the ancient [[Chiu Monastery]] built on a steep hill, looking as if it has been carved right out of the rock. The lake is very popular in Buddhist literature and associated with many teachings and stories. Buddha, it is reported, stayed and meditated near this lake on several occasions. Lake Manasarovar is also the subject of the meditative Tibetan tradition, "The Jewel of Tibet". A modern narration and description of the meditation was made popular by [[Robert Thurman]].[http://www.soundstrue.com/shop/420.productdetails?couponCode=NOVAA The Jewel Tree of Tibet – Robert Thurman]. Soundstrue.com. Retrieved on 2013-07-18. === In Jainism === In [[Jainism]], Lake Manasarovar is associated with the first [[Tirthankara]], [[Rishabha]]. As per Jain scriptures, the first Tirthankar, Bhagwan Rushabhdev, had attained [[nirvana]] on the Ashtapad Mountain. The son of Bhagwan Rishabhdev, [[Bharata Chakravartin|Chakravati Bharat]], had built a palace adorned with gems on the Ashtapad Mountain located in the serene [[Himalayas]].There are many stories related to Ashtapad Maha Tirth like Kumar and Sagar's sons, Tapas Kher Parna, Ravan and Mandodri Bhakti, among many others. {{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/lifestyle/report-lost-tirth-of-jains-traced-to-himalayas-1631581|title='Lost' tirth of Jains traced to Himalayas - Latest News & Updates at Daily News & Analysis|author=|date=30 December 2011|website=dnaindia.com|accessdate=29 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170815022808/http://www.dnaindia.com/lifestyle/report-lost-tirth-of-jains-traced-to-himalayas-1631581|archivedate=15 August 2017|df=}} ==See also== * [[Rakshas Tal]] * [[Lakes of India]] == References == == External links == {{Commons category|Lake Manasarovar}} {{Wikivoyage|Mount_Kailash}} {{Hinduism (compact)}} {{Buddhist temples in China}} {{Lakes of China}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Manasarovar}} [[Category:Lakes of the Tibet Autonomous Region]] [[Category:Hindu pilgrimage sites]] [[Category:Sacred lakes]] [[Category:Indus basin]] [[Category:Hindu temples in China]] [[Category:Buddhist temples in China]]

The '''Leaf Angle Distribution''' (or LAD) of a plant canopy refers to the mathematical description of the angular [[Orientation (geometry)|orientation]] of the [[Leaf|leaves]] in the [[vegetation]]. Specifically, if each leaf is conceptually represented by a small flat plate, its orientation can be described with the [[zenith]] and the [[azimuth]] angles of the [[surface normal]] to that plate. If the leaf has a complex structure and is not flat, it may be necessary to approximate the actual leaf by a set of small plates, in which case there may be a number of leaf normals and associated angles. The LAD describes the statistical distribution of these angles.
==Examples of Leaf Angle Distributions==
Different plant canopies exhibit different LADs: For instance, grasses and willows have their leaves largely hanging vertically (such plants are said to have an erectophile LAD), while oaks tend to maintain their leaves more or less horizontally (these species are known as having a planophile LAD). In some tree species, leaves near the top of the [[Canopy (forest)|canopy]] follow an erectophile LAD while those at the bottom of the canopy are more planophile. This may be interpreted as a strategy by that plant species to maximize exposure to light, an important constraint to growth and development. Yet other species (notably [[sunflower]]) are capable of reorienting their leaves throughout the day to optimize exposure to the Sun: this is known as [[heliotropism]].
==Importance of LAD==
The LAD of a plant canopy has a significant impact on the [[Reflection (physics)|reflectance]], [[transmittance]] and [[Absorption (electromagnetic radiation)|absorption]] of solar light in the vegetation layer, and thus also on its growth and development. LAD can also serve as a quantitative index to monitor the state of the plants, as [[wilting]] usually results in more erectophile LADs. [[Scientific modelling|Models]] of [[radiation]] transfer need to take this distribution into account to predict, for instance, the [[albedo]] or the productivity of the canopy.
==Measuring LAD==
Accurately measuring the statistical properties of leaf angle distributions is not a trivial matter, especially for small leaves. [[Clinometer]]s can be used but may be rather bulky or inconvenient. Most leaves are quite light and tend to move with the slightest [[Wind|breeze]] or air [[turbulence]]. Nevertheless, when these environmental conditions are suitable or can be controlled, it is possible to acquire data on leaf orientation.
This may be done, for instance, with a Spatial Coordinate Apparatus, which is an articulated mechanical device capable or recording the position in three-dimensional space of three separate points forming a small triangle. The orientation of the triangle is computed from these coordinates.
Yet another approach is to use a [[3D_scanner|laser scanner]]: this instrument can record the angular and distance coordinates of the intersection of a laser beam with objects within its range. The LAD of canopy leaves can be derived from such measurements.
Extensive data sets of LAD have been recorded, especially during intensive field campaigns, such as the First ISLSCP Field Experiment (FIFE) or the SAFARI 2000 field campaign. See the external links below for getting access to these data.
==LAD functions==
In general, LAD are modelled with one- or two-parameters functions including ellipsoidal, rotated-ellipsoidal and Beta functions. Comparison between different LAD functions with in-situ measurements show that, two-parameter functions (especially Beta function) may perform better than one-parameter functions.
==References==
* J. Ross (1981) ''The Radiation Regime and Architecture of Plant Stands'', 391 pp., W. Junk, Boston, Massachusetts. * David M. Gates (1980) ''Biophysical Ecology'', Springer-Verlag, New York, 611 pp., {{ISBN|0-387-90414-X}} (especially pages 379-381). * Wang W. M., Li Z.-L. and Su H.-B., 2007, ''Comparison of leaf angle distribution functions: effects on extinction coefficient and sunlit foliage'', Agricultural and Forest Meteorology, 2007, Vol. 143, NO. 1-2, pp. 106-122.
==External links==
* Non accessible as of July 3, 2018: http://www.daac.ornl.gov/FIFE/Datasets/Vegetation/Leaf_Angle_Data.html * Non accessible as of July 3, 2018: http://www.daac.ornl.gov/S2K/guides/kt_canopy_structure.html

[[Image:Hurricane Nora Remnants 1997.JPG|thumb|The remnants of [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Hurricane Nora]] over the southwestern United States|230px|right]]<onlyinclude><!-- See [[Wikipedia_talk:Featured_lists#Proposed_change_to_all_featured_lists]] for an explanation of this and other inclusion tags below -->A '''California hurricane''' is a [[tropical cyclone]] that affects the state of [[California]]. Usually, only the remnants of tropical cyclones affect California. Since 1900, only two tropical storms have hit California, one by direct landfall from offshore, another after making landfall in [[Mexico]].</onlyinclude>
Since 1850, only seven tropical cyclones have brought gale-force winds to the [[Southwestern United States]]. They are: The [[1858 San Diego hurricane]] that was reconstructed as just missing landfall in 1858, the [[1939 California tropical storm|1939 Long Beach tropical storm]] that made landfall near [[San Pedro Bay (California)|San Pedro]] in 1939, the remnants of [[1963 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical_Storm_Jennifer-Katherine|Tropical Storm Jennifer-Katherine]] in 1963, the remnants of [[1965 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane_Emily|Hurricane Emily]] in 1965, the remnants of [[Hurricane Joanne (1972)|Hurricane Joanne]] in 1972, the remnants of [[Hurricane Kathleen (1976)|Hurricane Kathleen]] in 1976, and [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Hurricane Nora]] in 1997, after it was downgraded to a tropical storm.
In most cases, rainfall is the only effect that these cyclones have on California. Sometimes, the rainfall is severe enough to cause flooding and damage. For example, floods from Hurricane Kathleen devastated [[Ocotillo, California]] and killed several people.
==Explanation for rarity==
There are two reasons why tropical cyclones rarely strike California at tropical storm intensity or higher: [[sea surface temperatures]], and the usual [[Tropical cyclone#Steering winds|upper level steering winds]] in the eastern Pacific, with sea surface temperatures being more important.
Tropical cyclones usually require very warm water to depth, generally above 26.5 °C (80 °F) extending to a depth of 50 meters (160 ft).<ref name=A16>{{cite web | title=Subject: A16) Why do tropical cyclones require 80 °F (26.5 °C) ocean temperatures to form ? | work= Tropical Cyclone FAQ| url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/A16.html | accessdate=2007-12-25| author=[[Christopher Landsea]]|publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]]}}</ref> However, the waters off California are cold even in summer. They rarely rise above 24 °C (75 °F) in near-shore southern California,<ref name=G8>{{cite web|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/G8.html|title=Subject: G8) Why do hurricanes hit the East coast of the U.S., but never the West coast?|work=Tropical Cyclone FAQ|publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]]|author=[[Christopher Landsea]]|accessdate=2007-12-25}}</ref> and usually remain below 17 °C (63 °F) along most of the rest of the coast and outer coastal waters, although [[El Niño]] events may warm the waters somewhat. This is due primarily to the extensive [[upwelling]] of colder sub-surface waters caused by the prevailing northwesterly winds acting through the [[Ekman spiral|Ekman Effect]]. The winds drive surface water to the right of the wind flow, that is offshore, which draws water up from below to replace it. The upwelling further cools the already cool [[California Current]] which runs north to south along coastal California and even much of coastal [[Baja California]]. This is the same mechanism which produces coastal California's characteristic fog.
The second reason is the general path of tropical cyclones in the eastern Pacific. They generally move north-westward or westward due to steering by the prevailing upper level winds, which takes them far out to sea and away from land.<ref name=G8/>
These factors make eastern Pacific landfalls improbable north of about central Baja California. In those instances when upper level steering winds do allow a more northerly path, much cooler sea surface temperatures quickly weaken tropical cyclones that approach California, although torrential rainfall can still occur. For example, the September 24-hour rainfall record for [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]] is held by the [[1939 Long Beach Tropical Storm]], as of January 2007.<ref name="history of sig events p14">{{cite web|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/sgx/document/weatherhistory.pdf#page=14|title=A History of Significant Weather Events in Southern California|date=February 2010|publisher=National Weather Service Forecast Office San Diego|format=PDF|page=14|accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref>
==List of tropical cyclones== Hurricanes that affect California are mainly the remnants of hurricanes or tropical storms. In the twentieth century, only four eastern Pacific tropical cyclones have brought tropical storm-force winds to the [[Continental United States]]: the [[1939 Long Beach Tropical Storm]], [[Hurricane Joanne (1972)|Tropical Storm Joanne]] in 1972, [[Hurricane Kathleen (1976)|Tropical Storm Kathleen]] in 1976, and [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Tropical Storm Nora]] in 1997.<ref name="sandiegohurricane">{{cite web|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/chenowethlandsea.pdf|title=The San Diego Hurricane of October 2, 1858|author=[[Christopher Landsea]] & Michael Chenoweth|publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]]|work=[[Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society]]|pages=1689|date=November 2004|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-12-26}}</ref>
===Pre–1930=== <onlyinclude> * After October 1854: A system considered to be a tropical cyclone made landfall over [[northern California]], just north of the [[Golden Gate]].<ref name=Visher>{{cite web|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/050/mwr-050-06-0295.pdf|title=Tropical Cyclones in the Northeast Pacific, Between Hawaii and Mexico|author=Stephen S. Visher|format=PDF|work=[[Monthly Weather Review]]|publisher=[[American Meteorological Society]]|pages=296|date=June 1922|accessdate=2007-12-26}}</ref> * October 2, 1858: The [[1858 San Diego hurricane]] passed very close to [[Southern California]]. It brought several hours of hurricane and gale-force winds to an area stretching from [[San Diego]] to [[Los Angeles]]. This storm was reconstructed as just missing making landfall, dissipating offshore.<ref name="sandiegohurricane"/> * Sometime before October 14, 1858: Since this tropical cyclone is reported in a newspaper as being only "one of the most terrific and violent hurricanes ever noted", the report may imply the existence of an earlier hurricane in southern California.<ref name="sandiegohurricane"/> Other than occurring before the newspaper account was published (October 18, 1858), everything else about this "hurricane", including whether it even existed, is unknown.<ref name="sandiegohurricane"/> * Before June or after October 1859: A system considered to be a tropical cyclone made landfall between [[Cape Mendocino]] and [[San Francisco Bay]].<ref name=Visher/> * August 11–12, 1873: Rain from a tropical storm fell on [[San Diego, California|San Diego]]. The rain on August 12 set a record for wettest August day.<ref name="history of sig events p4">{{cite web|pages=4|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/sgx/document/weatherhistory.pdf#page=4|title=A History of Significant Weather Events in Southern California|format=PDF|publisher=National Weather Service Forecast Office San Diego|accessdate=16 January 2016|date=February 2010}}</ref> * July 20–21, 1902: The remnants of a hurricane brought rain to southern California.<ref name=Williams>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/weather/whhcalif.htm|title=California's Tropical Cyclones|author=Jack Williams|publisher=[[USA Today]]|date=2005-05-17|accessdate=2007-12-26}}</ref> * August 18–19, 1906: A tropical cyclone moved northward from the [[Gulf of California]], and brought rain to southern California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 15, 1910: The remnants of a hurricane brought rain to [[Santa Barbara County]].<ref name=Williams/> * August 26, 1915: The remnants of a tropical cyclone brought around an inch of rain to [[Riverside, California|Riverside]].<ref name=Williams/> * September 11–12, 1918: The remnants of a tropical cyclone produced six inches (150 mm) of rain to the mountains of southern California.<ref name=Williams/> * August 20–21, 1921: A tropical cyclone moved north from [[Baja California]] and into Arizona, producing rain in both southern California and Arizona.<ref name=Williams/> * September 30, 1921: The remnants of a tropical cyclone moved northward from Baja California, and brought rain to Arizona and parts of California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 18, 1929: A tropical cyclone in the Pacific Ocean dropped rain over southern California.<ref name=Williams/></onlyinclude>
===1930s=== * September 28–October 1, 1932: The remnants of a hurricane brought four days of rain. Flash floods killed 15 people.<ref name=Williams/> * August 25, 1935: A tropical cyclone moved northward from the south, and brought rain to southern California and parts of Arizona.<ref name=Williams/> * August 9, 1936: A hurricane's remnants moved north and brought heavy rains to the [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]] area.<ref name=Williams/> * September 4–7, 1939: The remnants of a hurricane brought over a year's worth of rain to parts of southern California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 11–12, 1939: The remnants of a hurricane from the Gulf of California brought rain to parts of California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 19–21, 1939: The remnants of a tropical cyclone brought rain to California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 25, 1939: The [[1939 California tropical storm]] made landfall near [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]].<ref name=Williams/> Winds were near 80 km/h (50 mph) and rain was near 12 inches (300 mm). At sea, 48 people were killed. On land, 45 were killed in flooding, although these deaths may be partially attributable to a nasty thunderstorm immediately preceding the tropical storm.<ref name="history of sig events p14"/> This is the only known landfall in California by a tropical cyclone at tropical storm strength, during the twentieth century.<ref name=Williams/>
===1940s=== * September 1941: Moisture from a hurricane brought rain to California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 9–10, 1945: The remnants of a tropical cyclone moved northward and brought rain to southern California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 30–October 1, 1946: The remnants of a tropical storm brought several inches of rain to California.<ref name=Williams/>
===1950s=== * August 27–29, 1951: The remnants of a tropical cyclone brought enough rain to wash out some roads in southern California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 19–21, 1952: The remnants of a hurricane brought rain to mountains in southern California.<ref name=Williams/> * July 17–19, 1954: The remnants of a hurricane moved into Arizona, bringing rain to the state and parts of California.<ref name=Williams/> * October 1–6, 1958: The remnants of a hurricane moved into Arizona, causing heavy rain in that state and in parts of California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 11, 1959: The remnants of a hurricane generated some rain over California.<ref name=Williams/>
===1960s=== * September 9–10, 1960: The remnants of [[1960 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Estelle|Hurricane Estelle]] generated rain over California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 17–19, 1963: [[1963 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Jennifer-Katherine|Tropical Storm Jennifer-Katherine]]<ref name="Unisys Jen-Kath">{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1963/JEN-KATH/track.gif|title=Tropical Storm Jen-Kath|format=GIF|publisher=Unisys|accessdate=2007-12-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070102121511/http://weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1963/JEN-KATH/track.gif|archive-date=2007-01-02|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> dissipated over northern Baja California, and dropped several inches of rain over California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 4–5, 1965: [[1965 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Emily|Hurricane Emily]]'s remnants brought rainfall to California.<ref name=Williams/>
===1970s=== [[Image:Hurricane Heather 1977.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Hurricane Heather on October 5, 1977]] * September 30–October 1, 1971: Atlantic [[Hurricane Irene–Olivia|Hurricane Irene]] crossed Central America and became [[1971 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Olivia|Hurricane Olivia]]. Olivia eventually re-curved and made landfall in Baja California, with the remnants bringing rain to California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 3, 1972: [[1972 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Hyacinth|Tropical Depression Hyacinth]] made landfall in California<ref name="Unisys Hyacinth">{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1972/HYACINTH/track.gif|format=GIF|title=Hurricane HYACINTH|accessdate=2007-12-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070103234848/http://weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1972/HYACINTH/track.gif|archive-date=2007-01-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> and produced rain in the area of Los Angeles.<ref name=Williams/> * October 6, 1972: [[1972 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Joanne|Hurricane Joanne]] made landfall in Mexico and managed to bring gale-force winds and rain to Arizona, as well as California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 9–12, 1976: [[Hurricane Kathleen (1976)|Hurricane Kathleen]] crossed the [[Baja California peninsula]] moved into California as a tropical storm. [[Yuma, Arizona]] reported sustained winds of 91 km/h (57 mph).<ref name=Williams/> Rains from Kathleen caused catastrophic damage to [[Ocotillo, California]] and killed three<ref name=Williams/> to six people.<ref name="history of sig events p31">{{cite web|pages=31|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/sgx/document/weatherhistory.pdf#page=31|title=A History of Significant Weather Events in Southern California|format=PDF|publisher=National Weather Service Forecast Office San Diego|accessdate=16 January 2016|date=February 2010}}</ref> * August 18–19, 1977: [[1977 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Doreen|Hurricane Doreen]] denegerated into a remnant low off the coast of California.<ref name=Williams/> The remnants moved inland and caused flooding and crop damage as 7.01 inches (178 mm) of rain fell on Yuma Valley, Arizona.{{Tropical Cyclone Point Maxima}} * October 6–7, 1977: [[1977 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Heather|Hurricane Heather]]'s remnants moved into Arizona, bringing 8.30 inches (211 mm) of rain to Nogales, Arizona and up to 14 inches (360 mm) of rainfall to the adjacent mountains. The remnants also brought significant rainfall to southern California. This led to significant flooding in both states.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/heather1977.html|title=Hurricane Heather - October 5-8, 1977|author=David Roth|publisher=}}</ref> * September 5–6, 1978: [[Hurricane Norman (1978)|Tropical Depression Norman]] made landfall in California.<ref name="Unisys Norman">{{cite web|title=Hurricane NORMAN|format=GIF|url=http://www.weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1978/NORMAN/track.gif|accessdate=2007-12-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070102115718/http://weather.unisys.com/hurricane/e_pacific/1978/NORMAN/track.gif|archive-date=2007-01-02|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Its remnants produced several inches of rain.<ref name=Williams/>
===1980s=== * June 29–30, 1980: [[1980 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Celia|Hurricane Celia]]'s remnants produced a minor amount of rain over California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 17–18, 1982: Remnants from [[1982 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Norman|Hurricane Norman]] generated rain over Arizona and southern California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 24–26, 1982: The remnants of [[1982 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Olivia|Hurricane Olivia]] produced over 7 inches (177 mm) of rain in California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 20–21, 1983: The remnants of [[1983 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Manuel|Hurricane Manuel]] produced rain in California.<ref name=Williams/> * October 7, 1983: The very weak remnants of [[1983 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Priscilla|Hurricane Priscilla]] caused showers in Southern California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 10–11, 1984: [[1984 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Marie|Hurricane Marie]]'s weak remnants generated showers over Southern California.<ref name=Williams/> * September 22–23, 1987: The remnants of [[1987 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Norma|Hurricane Norma]] generated thunderstorms over Southern California, which caused some flooding.<ref name="history of sig events p37">{{cite web|pages=37|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/sgx/document/weatherhistory.pdf#page=37|title=A History of Significant Weather Events in Southern California|format=PDF|publisher=National Weather Service Forecast Office San Diego|accessdate=16 January 2016|date=February 2010}}</ref> * October 5–12, 1987: Weather associated with [[Hurricane Ramon]] caused moderate to heavy rain in southern [[California]]. The highest amount noted was 2.14 inches (54 mm) at Camp Pendleton.<ref name="history of sig events p37"/> * September 1989: [[Hurricane Octave (1989)|Hurricane Octave]]'s remnants brought rain to California, doing minimal damage.<ref name="NHC Octave 1989">{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/epacific/ep1989-prelim/octave/prelim02.gif|title=Preliminary Report Hurricane Octave (file 2)|author=Gil Clark|publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]]|accessdate=2007-12-26|format=GIF|date=1989-11-09}}</ref>
===1990s=== [[Image:Hurricane Linda 12 sept 1997 2100Z.jpg|thumb|Hurricane Linda on September 12, 1997|250px|right]] * June 1990: The remnants of [[1990 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Boris|Hurricane Boris]] briefly caused heavy rainfall in Southern California. This was one of the reasons why it was the wettest June in [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], since record-keeping began in 1850.<ref name="NHC Boris 1990">{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/epacific/ep1990-prelim/boris/prelim02.gif|title=Preliminary Report Hurricane Boris 9 (file 2)|accessdate=2007-12-16|author=[[Max Mayfield]]|format=GIF}}</ref> Despite this, less than an inch (25 mm) of rain fell in most locations.<ref name="HPC Boris 1990 rain">{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/boris1990rain.gif|title=Remains of Boris|format=GIF|publisher=[[Hydrometeorological Prediction Center]]|accessdate=2007-12-26}}</ref> * July 1992: The remnants of [[1992 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Darby|Hurricane Darby]] caused cloudiness in California. These clouds were also enough to delay the landing of the [[Space Shuttle Columbia|Space Shuttle ''Columbia'']] for a day, and cause it to land in [[Florida]] instead of California.<ref name="NHC Darby 1992">{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/epacific/ep1992-prelim/darby/prelim03.gif|title=Preliminary Report Hurricane Darby (file 3)|date=1992-08-09|author=[[Max Mayfield]]|format=GIF|publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]]|accessdate=2007-12-26}}</ref> * August 1992: [[Hurricane Lester (1992)|Hurricane Lester]]'s remnants caused rain in extreme Southern California.<ref name="HPC Lester 1992">{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/lester1992rain.gif|title=Hurricane Lester|publisher=[[Hydrometeorological Prediction Center]]|format=GIF|accessdate=2007-12-26}}</ref> * August 5, 1997: Surf from [[Hurricane Guillermo (1997)|Hurricane Guillermo]] caused [[rip current]]s near [[Corona Del Mar, California|Corona Del Mar]], and a place just north of [[Huntington Beach, California|Huntington Beach]], injuring three people and killing one.<ref name="Guillermo riptide">{{cite web|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~283099|title=Event Record Details|publisher=[[National Climatic Data Center]]|accessdate=2007-12-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5r1WULh4K?url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~283099|archivedate=2010-07-06|df=}}</ref> * August 19–20, 1997: [[1997 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Ignacio|Tropical Storm Ignacio]]'s remnants produced gusty winds over the outer waters of California, and passed directly over the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], before moving across the interior of the [[Pacific Northwest]]. Sporadic moderate to heavy rainfall was recorded in both California and the states of the Pacific Northwest.<ref name="HPC Ignacio">{{cite web|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/ignacio1997.html|title=Remains of Ignacio|publisher=[[Hydrometeorological Prediction Center]]|accessdate=2007-12-26}}</ref> * September 13–14, 1997: [[Hurricane Linda (1997)|Hurricane Linda]] was at one point forecast to make landfall in Southern California.<ref name="nhclinda1997">{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/1997linda.html|title=Preliminary Report Hurricane Linda|author=[[Max Mayfield]]|date=1997-10-25|publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]]|accessdate=2007-12-26}}</ref> Instead, it moved out to sea, although large waves caused by Linda did wash five people off a jetty in [[Newport Beach, California|Newport Beach]].<ref name="nhclinda1997"/> Also, Linda's outer rainbands generated thunderstorms over southern California, causing [[flash flood]]s in some regions. * September 25–26, 1997: After making landfall in Baja California, [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Hurricane Nora]] maintained tropical storm status into California and Arizona. Moderate to heavy rains fell across southeast California and Arizona, with a new 24-hour maximum for Arizona  (305 mm (12 inches) falling in the Mogollon Rim). Damage totaled several hundred million, including $40 million (1997 USD) to lemon trees. There were a few indirect deaths caused by the hurricane.<ref name="nhcnora1997">{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/1997nora.html |title=Preliminary Report Hurricane Nora |date=1997-10-30 |author=[[Edward Rappaport]] |accessdate=2007-12-26 |publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050925163209/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/1997nora.html |archivedate=2005-09-25 |df= }}</ref>
===2000s=== * September 2000: The remnants of [[2000 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Lane|Hurricane Lane]] triggered thunderstorms across California.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/weather/huricane/2000/epacific/wlane.htm |title=Hurricane Lane brushes Mexican peninsula |last=Cappella |first=Chris |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5y5vt2gOa?url=http://www.usatoday.com/weather/huricane/2000/epacific/wlane.htm |archivedate=April 20, 2011 |year=2000 |work=USA Today |accessdate=April 20, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }}</ref> * September 2001: Remnant moisture from [[2001 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Flossie|Hurricane Flossie]] caused thunderstorms, lightning, and floods in [[Southern California]]. Lightning struck four people, killing two of them.<ref name="NHC Flossie 2001">{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2001flossie.html|title=Tropical Cyclone Report Hurricane Flossie|date=2001-10-27|author=Stacy R. Stewart|accessdate=2007-12-26|publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]]}}</ref> * September 30, 2001: Thunderstorms from the remnants of [[Hurricane Juliette (2001)|Hurricane Juliette]] caused minor damage to California<ref name="NHC Juliette 2001">{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2001juliette.html |title=Tropical Cyclone Report Hurricane Juliette |date=2001-11-30 |author=Miles B. Laswrence & Michelle Mainelli |accessdate=2007-12-26 |publisher=[[National Hurricane Center]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006122021/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/2001juliette.html |archivedate=2008-10-06 |df= }}</ref> and brought rain of less than an inch (25 mm) to the area.<ref name="WPCMAX"/> * August 2003: Remnants of [[Hurricane Ignacio (2003)|Hurricane Ignacio]] produced powerful thunderstorms in southern California. * September 2003: Remnants of [[Hurricane Marty (2003)|Hurricane Marty]] dropped large amounts of rainfall, in the [[southwestern United States]], especially in Southern California and southwestern Arizona. * July 2006: Remnants of [[Tropical Storm Emilia (2006)|Tropical Storm Emilia]] caused unsettled weather across the southwestern United States. Rain from the remnants helped to extinguish the Horse Fire in southern California.<ref>{{cite web|author=San Diego Union Tribune|date=2006-07-30|title=Horse fire declared fully contained|accessdate=2008-09-19|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/metro/20060730-1100-horsefire.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120919085953/http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/metro/20060730-1100-horsefire.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-09-19}}</ref> * September 2006: Remnants of [[Hurricane John (2006)|Hurricane John]] triggered flash flood watches.<ref name="NWS SD CA Sept 4 2006">[[Wikisource:September 4, 2006 NWS San Diego Flash Flood Watch]]</ref> * August 26–27, 2007: Remnants of [[Hurricane Dean]] made landfall in [[Santa Barbara County, California|Santa Barbara area]], triggering heavy rains and minor flooding throughout the southern California Area. Early on August 27, the storm eventually reached [[Las Vegas, Nevada]], and caused flash flooding there as well, before dissipating there later in the day. * August 25, 2008: Remnants of [[Tropical Storm Julio (2008)|Tropical Storm Julio]] reached the [[Apple Valley, California]], and [[Las Vegas, Nevada]]. * August 27–29, 2009: Remnants of [[2009 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Ignacio|Tropical Storm Ignacio]] triggered heavy rains across northern and central California. * September 4, 2009: Remnants of [[Hurricane Jimena (2009)|Hurricane Jimena]] caused [[severe thunderstorm]]s to break out in eastern [[San Diego County, California]], causing flash floods, and a short blackout that lasted for only a few hours. * October 11–15, 2009: The [[October 2009 North American storm complex|remnants]] of [[Typhoon Melor (2009)|Typhoon Melor]] affected California and broke several rainfall records. The storm system also opened up a [[Pineapple Express]], an [[atmospheric river]] originating near Hawaii.
===2010s=== [[Image:Odile 2014-09-14 0600Z.jpg|thumb|Hurricane Odile on September 14, 2014|250px|right]] *July 18–20, 2012: Associated moisture and clouds from the remnants of [[2012 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Fabio|Hurricane Fabio]] generated scattered showers and isolated thunderstorms across the [[Los Angeles Basin]].<ref name="Hurricane Fabio remnants cause thunder across southern California">{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2012/07/thunder-southern-california-hurricane-fabio.html|title=Hurricane Fabio remnants cause thunder across southern California|date=2012-07-18|author=Robert J. Lopez|accessdate=2012-07-19|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]}}</ref> *September 5–7, 2012: Moisture from the remnants of [[2012 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm John|Tropical Storm John]] brought scattered showers and thunderstorms to California.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/tropical-storms-last-gasp-aids-calif-firefighters/|title=Tropical storm's last gasp aids Calif. firefighters|date=6 September 2012|publisher=}}</ref> *August 25–26, 2013: Moisture from the remnants of [[2013 Pacific hurricane season#Tropical Storm Ivo|Tropical Storm Ivo]] caused some thunderstorms and flooding in southern California.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2013/aug/26/thunderstorms-pound-s-cal-for-second-day/|title=Thunderstorms pound S. Cal for second day|date=26 August 2013|work=The San Diego Union-Tribune}}</ref> *September 3, 2013: Moisture from the remnants of [[2013 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Kiko|Hurricane Kiko]] fueled the monsoon across the Southwestern United States, producing scattered showers and thunderstorms across the region.<ref>{{cite news|title=U.S. Drought Monitor Report for the Week Ending Sept. 3 (Text)|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-09-06/u-s-drought-monitor-report-for-the-week-ending-sept-3-text-.html|accessdate=September 6, 2013|newspaper=Bloomberg|date=September 6, 2013}}</ref> *August 26–29, 2014: Large swells from [[Hurricane Marie (2014)|Hurricane Marie]] caused high waves and rip currents.<ref>{{cite news|title=Day 3 of Big Waves Expected in Southern California|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/california-beach-town-sees-flooding-hurricane-25148943|date=2014-08-28|author=Gillian Flaccus|accessdate=August 28, 2013|publisher=Associated Press}}</ref> *September 8, 2014: The remnants of [[Hurricane Norbert (2014)|Hurricane Norbert]] caused thunderstorms and flooding in Southern California.<ref>{{cite news|title=Norbert weakens to tropical storm off Mexico; causes flooding in Southern California|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2014/09/08/norbert-weakens-to-tropical-storm-off-mexico-causes-flooding-in-southern/|date=September 8, 2014|accessdate=September 8, 2014|publisher=Associated Press}}</ref> *September 16–17, 2014: [[Hurricane Odile]]'s outer rainbands brought thunderstorms to parts of Southern California, as a tropical storm. The remnants of Hurricane Odile also caused damage across central and eastern [[San Diego County]] on September 16, 2014, generating high winds and several uncharacteristically powerful thunderstorms in the region. Wind gusts over 20 knots reportedly uprooting trees, felled branches, cut power lines, crushed several cars, and flipped at least one airplane at [[Montgomery Field]] Airport.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2014/sep/16/heat-thunder-storms-san-diego/|title=100-degree heat, thunderstorms turn San Diego suddenly into Florida - SanDiegoUnionTribune.com|date=16 September 2014|work=The San Diego Union-Tribune}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2014/sep/17/storm-fallen-trees-branches-damage/|title=Storm passed through San Diego, cleanup begins — with trees - SanDiegoUnionTribune.com|date=17 September 2014|work=The San Diego Union-Tribune}}</ref> [[Dry lightning]] generated by a line of severe thunderstorms in one of the rainbands set fire to a palm tree in San Diego<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/kitcorry/status/512045468030083073|title=Kit Corry|work=Twitter}}</ref> and storm force wind gusts within those severe thunderstorms left 6000 customers without power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcsandiego.com/news/local/Sig-Alert-Issued-Thousand-Lose-Power-in-Surprise-Storm-275380541.html|title=Traffic Blocked, Thousands Lose Power in Surprise Storm|work=NBC 7 San Diego}}</ref> *October 6–7, 2014: [[2014 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Simon|Hurricane Simon]]'s outer rainbands bring scattered thunderstorms and flash floods to parts of Southern California as a tropical storm, and later as a tropical depression, with a brief rain shower in San Diego County on October 7. *June 9–10, 2015: A low pressure system containing the remnants of [[2015 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Blanca|Hurricane Blanca]] brought showers to Southern California on June 9.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-june-rainfall-records-20150610-story.html|title=The rain wasn't much, but it broke records for June|author=Los Angeles Times|date=10 June 2015|work=latimes.com}}</ref> Some flooding was reported in Santa Barbara County. On June 10, the low pressure system moved north to the San Francisco Bay Area and brought scattered showers there as well. Many rainfall records were broken.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abc7news.com/weather/rare-june-storm-brings-rain-to-bay-area/776402/|title=Rare June storm brings rain to the Bay Area|work=ABC7 San Francisco}}</ref> *July 18–20, 2015: The remnants of [[2015 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Dolores|Hurricane Dolores]] brought scattered showers and thunderstorms throughout Southern California, breaking many rainfall records and causing flooding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-thunderstorms-weekend-20150717-story.html|title=Rain, thunder and lightning pound L.A. area; flooding possible|author=Los Angeles Times|date=18 July 2015|work=latimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ramonasentinel.com/news/2015/jul/19/weather-service-issues-flood-advisory/|title=Weather service issues flood advisory until 4:30 Sunday afternoon|author=Maureen Robertson|work=Ramona Sentinel}}</ref> One such flash flood caused a bridge to collapse which shut down [[Interstate 10#California|Interstate 10]] between [[Indio, California|Indio]] and [[Blythe, California|Blythe]], effectively shutting off the primary Phoenix-to-Los-Angeles route.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pe.com/articles/highway-773881-bridge-caltrans.html|title=I-10 CLOSURE: Collapsed bridge received high marks in last inspection|author=JANET ZIMMERMAN and DEBRA GRUSZECKI|date=20 July 2015|work=Press Enterprise}}</ref> The good news was that the rain helped firefighters contain the [[North Fire]] within 3 days. *August 6, 2015: [[2015 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Guillermo|Hurricane Guillermo]] interacted with a longwave trough in the subtropical jet to its northeast to spawn a rare dry-season [[atmospheric river]],<ref name="weatherwest.com">http://www.weatherwest.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/wv.jpg</ref> which went on to send moisture toward the San Francisco Bay Area, bringing a rare lightning storm to that area that night. Since the storm was dry and hardly brought any rain, the NWS issued a [[Red Flag Warning]] for that area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abc7news.com/weather/nws-declares-red-flag-warning-for-bay-area;-cal-fire-on-alert/908880/|title=National Weather Service declares red flag warning for Bay Area; Cal Fire on alert|work=ABC7 San Francisco}}</ref> *September 8–15, 2015: The remnants of [[Hurricane Linda (2015)|Hurricane Linda]] brought localized downpours from Santa Barbara to San Diego, California.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accuweather.com/en/weather-news/linda-thunderstorms-rain-southern-california/52334320?partner_code=andtablet|title=Moisture From Linda to Bring Rain to Southern California Early This Week|work=AccuWeather}}</ref> On September 15, Los Angeles received 2.39 inches of rain, making it one of the wettest September days since records dating back to 1877,<ref>{{cite web|title=Hurricane Linda’s remnants drench Los Angeles with wettest September days in decades|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/capital-weather-gang/wp/2015/09/15/hurricane-lindas-remnants-drench-los-angeles-with-wettest-september-day-in-decades/|date=September 15, 2015|author=Samenow, Jason|accessdate=September 25, 2015|publisher=The Washington Post}}</ref> second only to [[List of California hurricanes#1930s|1939]]. *July 11–12, 2017: Dangerous rip currents from [[2017 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Eugene|Hurricane Eugene]] combined with swells of 4 to 8 ft (1.2 to 2.4 m) across Southern California.<ref>{{cite web|author=Gary Robbins|title=Hurricane Eugene will bring big waves to parts of Southern California coast|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-hurricane-20170710-story.html|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=July 10, 2017|accessdate=July 8, 2018}}</ref> *September 3–4, 2017: Moisture from [[Tropical Storm Lidia (2017)|Tropical Storm Lidia]]'s remnant low brought flash flooding and thunderstorms to Southern California. Lidia's remnants also triggered a [[microburst]] event in [[Santa Barbara, California|Santa Barbara]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.com/news/2017/sep/05/teen-severely-injured-microburst|title=Teen Severely Injured by Santa Barbara Microburst|date=September 5, 2017|newspaper=Santa Barbara Independent|accessdate=September 7, 2017}}</ref> *July 7–8, 2018: As a tropical storm, [[2018 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Fabio|Hurricane Fabio]] brought rip currents to the coastline of California, and showers and humid conditions to Northern California.<ref>{{cite web|author=Amy Graff|title=Fading Hurricane Fabio delivers muggy weather and dangerous surf to Northern California|url=https://www.sfgate.com/weather/article/Hurricane-Fabio-beach-hazard-statement-muggy-hot-13054158.php|publisher=San Francisco Chronicle|date=July 6, 2018|accessdate=July 8, 2018}}</ref> *August 9–11, 2018: [[2018 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane John|Hurricane John]] brought high surf to the coast of Southern California.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.accuweather.com/en/weather-news/dangerous-surf-from-hurricane-john-to-affect-southern-california-beaches-friday-saturday/70005727|title=Dangerous surf from John to affect Southern California beaches into this weekend|author=Alex Sosnowski|publisher=AccuWeather|date=August 10, 2018|accessdate=August 10, 2018}}</ref> *October 1, 2018: [[Hurricane Rosa (2018)|Hurricane Rosa]] brought scattered thunderstorms to parts of Southern California as a tropical storm, triggering flash flood watches in [[San Diego County, California|San Diego County]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://patch.com/california/san-diego/hurricane-rosa-remnants-drop-rain-san-diego-region|author=|publisher=San Diego Patch|date=October 1, 2018|accessdate=October 3, 2018}}</ref> *October 12, 2018: The remnants of [[Hurricane Sergio (2018)|Hurricane Sergio]] spawned numerous thunderstorms in Southern California, as well as triggering a high surf advisory along the coast. One thunderstorm made by the remnants of Sergio caused a power outage in [[Montebello, California|Montebello]] that lasted from 10:00 P.M. to 1:00 A.M. PT (Pacific Time).
==Climatological statistics== Most tropical cyclones impacting California do so in the month of September. September 1939 was "unprecedented" in having four tropical cyclones impact the state.<ref name="history of sig events p13">{{cite web|url=http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/sgx/document/weatherhistory.pdf#page=14|title=A History of Significant Weather Events in Southern California|format=PDF|pages=13–14|publisher=National Weather Service Forecast Office San Diego|accessdate=16 January 2016|date=February 2010}}</ref>
{{bar graph|float=center | title = Number of recorded storms affecting California, by month of year | data_max = 50 | label_type = Month | data_type = Number of storms | label1 = January | data1 = 0 | label2 = February | data2 = 0 | label3 = March | data3 = 0 | label4 = April | data4 = 0 | label5 = May | data5 = 0 | label6 = June | data6 = 4 | label7 = July | data7 = 7 | label8 = August | data8 = 18 | label9 = September | data9 = 41 | label10 = October | data10 = 11 | label11 = November | data11 = 0 | label12 = December | data12 = 0 }}
{{bar graph|float=center | title = Number of recorded storms affecting California by decade | data_max = 50 | label_type = Period | data_type = Number of storms | label1 = Pre-1930 | data1 = 11 | label2 = 1930s | data2 = 7 | label3 = 1940s | data3 = 3 | label4 = 1950s | data4 = 5 | label5 = 1960s | data5 = 3 | label6 = 1970s | data6 = 7 | label7 = 1980s | data7 = 9 | label8 = 1990s | data8 = 7 | label9 = 2000s | data9 = 11 | label10 = 2010s | data10 = 18 }}
==Deadliest storms== The following is a list of all known tropical cyclone-related deaths in California.
<center> {| class="wikitable sortable" align="center" |- ! Name ! Year ! Number of deaths |- | [[1939 California tropical storm|Unnamed]] || 1939 || 45–93 |- | Unnamed || 1932 || 15 |- | [[Hurricane Kathleen (1976)|Kathleen]] || 1976 || 3–6 |- | [[Hurricane Nora (1997)|Nora]] || 1997 || 3–4 |- | [[2001 Pacific hurricane season#Hurricane Flossie|Flossie]] || 2001 || 2 |- | [[Hurricane Guillermo (1997)|Guillermo]] || 1997 || 1 |} </center>
==Modern repeats== While rare, tropical cyclones do affect California, occasionally very seriously as far as rainfall is concerned.
===Damage=== [[Image:CaliforniaTropicalCycloneBreakpoints.png|thumb|350px|right|Map of warning breakpoints]]
A modern repeat of the 1858 storm is estimated to cause damages of hundreds of millions of dollars.<ref name="sandiegohurricane"/> A repeat of the 1939 tropical storm would cause around 200 million dollars in damage.<ref name="sandiegohurricane"/> The most serious damage would be due to rains rather than winds or storm surge, although distant hurricanes may still create heavy surf,<ref name="nhclinda1997"/> possibly injuring or killing people. Nora caused millions in damage and skirted extreme southeastern California.
===Preparedness=== When [[Hurricane Linda (1997)|Hurricane Linda]] was forecast to make landfall, statements about its possible impact were issued by the [[Oxnard, California]] office of the [[National Weather Service]]. They stressed the uncertainty of a forecast that far in the future.
When Nora was threatening, "unprecedented coordination" was required between the NHC and several other agencies. The coordination was "smooth and effective".<ref name="nhcnora1997"/> However, no inland tropical storm warnings were issued for any area in the United States as Nora was approaching from the south.<ref name="nhcnora1997"/>
There are seven Pacific Coast breakpoints in the United States. They are, from north to south, [[Piedras Blancas Light Station|Point Piedras Blancas]], [[Point Sal State Beach|Point Sal]], [[Point Conception]], [[Point Mugu, California|Point Mugu]], the mouth of the [[San Gabriel River (California)|San Gabriel River]], San Mateo Point, and the mouth of the [[Tijuana River]] (although places outside this area can be selected if conditions warrant).<ref name="nhccaliforniabreakpointslocations">{{cite web|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/breakpoints_list.shtml? |publisher=National Hurricane Center |title=Hurricane and Tropical Storm Watch/Warning Breakpoints |accessdate=2012-07-22 |date=2012-07-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070708223310/http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/breakpoints_list.shtml |archivedate=July 8, 2007 |df= }}</ref> Should there be the threat of landfall, [[tropical cyclone warnings and watches|warnings or watches]] would be issued for those sections of the coast. It is highly unlikely that any tropical cyclone will threaten areas farther north, due to the stronger influence of the [[California Current]].
==See also== {{Portal|Tropical cyclones}} * [[List of tropical cyclones]] * [[List of Arizona hurricanes]] * [[List of Baja California Peninsula hurricanes]] * [[List of Pacific hurricane seasons]] * [[Tropical cyclone]]

page.title: List of Solar System objects most distant from the Sun in 2018
List of Superfund sites in West Virginia

revision.text:
This is a '''list of Superfund sites in [[West Virginia]]''' designated under the [[Superfund|Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act]] (CERCLA) environmental law. The CERCLA federal law of 1980 authorized the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) to create a list of [[Pollution|polluted]] locations requiring a long-term response to clean up hazardous material contamination.P.L. 96-510, {{USC|42|9601|9675}}), December 11, 1980. These locations are known as [[Superfund]] sites, and are placed on the [[National Priorities List]] (NPL). The NPL guides the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]] in "determining which sites warrant further investigation" for [[environmental remediation]]. As of March 26, 2010, there were 9 Superfund sites on the National Priorities List in [[West Virginia]].{{cite web| url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/npl/ |title=National Priorities List |publisher=United States Enivironmental Protection Agency |accessdate=April 25, 2010}} No additional sites are currently proposed for entry on the list.
